item.title: Israel Calls On Civilians Near Hezbollah Targets to Evacuate as Strikes Intensify
item.description: The Israeli military launched a series of airstrikes in Lebanon in what it said was a pre-emptive strike targeting Hezbollah’s military infrastructure.

item.title: At the World's Largest Shipyard, U.S. Courts an Ally to Face Up to China
item.description: South Korea offers shipbuilding capacity, know-how and talent that rivals China, but American ships by law must be built in the U.S.

item.title: The Sports Star and Tabloid Fixture Staring Down Pakistan's Army
item.description: From jail, former Prime Minister Imran Khan still makes decisions big and small for the party he built. He tells the Journal he’s battling for democracy.

item.title: Russia and U.S. Religious Conservatives See Common Foe in Africa: Gay Rights
item.description: Unlikely coalition provides moral support for local activists pushing laws criminalizing homosexuality; death penalty in Uganda.

item.title: Israel and Hezbollah Slide Toward Full-Scale War in Night of Intense Strikes
item.description: The militant group said it targeted an air base and a developer of Israel’s Iron Dome system, while dozens of Israeli warplanes struck southern Lebanon.

item.title: Israeli Military Raids and Shuts Al Jazeera's West Bank Bureau
item.description: Troops entered the news outlet’s Ramallah office during a live broadcast and ordered staff out.

item.title: Biden's Iran Envoy Wanted a Nuclear Deal. It May Have Cost Him His Career.
item.description: Robert Malley, who was known for engaging adversaries and pushing the envelope on diplomacy, is under FBI investigation.

item.title: On Ukraine's Snake Island, the Heart of the Battle for the Black Sea
item.description: The Wall Street Journal was granted rare access to the island, which has been at the center of Ukraine’s efforts to challenge Russian power in the area.

item.title: Israel's Ultimatum to Hezbollah: Back Off or Go to War
item.description: A strategy shift includes escalating attacks aimed at forcing the militant group from the Lebanon-Israel border.

item.title: Israeli Strike Decimates Hezbollah Military Leadership
item.description: The militant group said 16 of its elite members were killed in Friday’s attack in Beirut, which Lebanon’s health minister said left a total of 37 people dead.

item.title: France's New Prime Minister Forms His Government, Shifting Rightward
item.description: The new cabinet remains largely dominated by ministers from the ranks of President Emmanuel Macron despite his party’s heavy losses in recent parliamentary elections.

item.title: Siege in Darfur Spirals Into a Brutal Battle for Control
item.description: An all-out assault of shelling and airstrikes on densely populated areas is exacerbating a famine crisis in Sudan’s El Fasher.

item.title: Taiwan Looks at Options as U.S. Weapons Supply Is Hit by Gaza and Ukraine
item.description: Delayed shipments have raised questions about what the island democracy can do to stockpile arms ahead of a potential conflict with China.

item.title: Russian Strikes on Power Grid Push Ukraine's Businesses to Breaking Point
item.description: Economists are cutting growth forecasts for Ukraine as companies struggle to hang on.

item.title: The Mysterious Trail of Hezbollah's Exploding Pagers
item.description: The attack on the militant group has prompted several investigations into the supply chain behind the devices that detonated this week.

item.title: Israel Kills Top Hezbollah Commander in Beirut Strike
item.description: The attack represents another security failure for the militant group that has been reeling from repeated Israeli blows.

item.title: Michaela DePrince, Who Survived Sierra Leone's Civil War to Become a Star Ballerina, Dies at 29
item.description: While living in an orphanage in her war-torn country, she dreamed of being happy, powerful and successful.

item.title: Why Putin's Attempt to Rewire Global Trade Is Faltering, in Charts and Maps
item.description: Moscow redirected oil sales, but forging new routes for other commodities proves difficult amid high costs and U.S. sanctions.

item.title: Pentagon Worries Israel Is Close to Launching Ground War in Lebanon
item.description: The wave of exploding electronic devices used by Hezbollah members could be a prelude to a wider attack by Israel.

item.title: Israel Scored a Stunning Blow Against Hezbollah. Its Path to Victory Is Less Clear.
item.description: Whether the one-two punch against the militant group results in a decisive victory remains in question.
